messages.text:
Are you looking to take a function `foo(a, x)` and turn it onto a function only of `x`? by subsituting `a=a0`? (also called partial evaluation)
that is done via creating a closure over `a0`
`foo_partial(x) = foo(a0, x)`
(or you could do it in anonymous function form:
`x->foo(a0, x)`

messages.text:
```curve_fit = (curve, data)
curve(a, x) = ...
a = ...
data = [...]
y = curve(a, data[:,1])
curve_fit(y, data)```

I think something might be being missed here
The `a` in  `a = ...` 
And the `a` in `curve(a, x)` are not at all linked to each other.
Those are different variables.
If you then did a call say `y = curve(a, data[:, 1])`
Then within that call they are the same variable.

messages.text: I'm sure this is not news to experienced Julia folks, but I was looking into Julia's comprehensions this evening, and I went through most of the examples in the List Comprehensions chapter of Graham Hutton's "Programming in Haskell" book. It was trivial to write similar Julia comprehensions, and I think they compare very favorably. You can see <https://blog.lojic.com/2020/12/26/comprehensions-in-julia.html|over a dozen side-by-side examples in my blog post>

messages.text: Is it possible to invoke a specific method stored in a vector of methods directly without overhead? I'm thinking of a scenario where a number of different methods are stored and given an index the respective method is called on some input arguments that are always the same, and the outputs would also be the same for all. This would be to avoid dynamic dispatch in a situation where there are different types being fed to a function and I want to call those methods more like c functions

messages.text:
Okay so I am doing some embedding Julia in c++. I'm calling a function pointer returned from `@cfunction` in c++ with one argument being a jl_value_t* that's created in c++. But here's the thing I want mutating the argument in Julia to actually mutate the jl_value_t* in c++. If I return a function pointer with `@cfunction($f, Bool, (ArgumentType,)` where ArgumentType is the mutable struct, it generates a copy and `pointer_from_objref` returns a different pointer each time I call the function pointer which makes me think it's creating a copy.... but if I do `@cfunction($f, Bool, (Any,)` , `pointer_from_objref` returns the same pointer as the jl_value_t* so no copy's being done and I get the desired effect. It's just I don't know the reason and I don't know how exactly Expr(:cfunction,..) inside the macro is handled. If anyone knows the reason or can direct me to some code, I'd appreciate it. Thanks for your time.

Edit: I am sending the function pointer to c++ like this
```function __register_cb_(f::Function)
    ccall(:api_register_cb, Nothing, (Ptr{Cvoid},), @cfunction($f, Bool, (Any,)))
end```
I am also using `JL_GC_PUSH1` so the jl_value_t* doesn't get garbage collected.

end

messages.text: Any way to ensure that compat bounds stay "correct"? Suppose I started developing package A and put B=0.1 in its dependencies. Then new versions of B come out, and A's compat is now B=0.1,0.2,0.3,0.4. But turns out that A uses some feature that appeared in B@0.3, and is not compatible with earlier versions anymore. How to catch this? `Pkg.test` installs latest versions that fit compats, so it will never catch the failure.

elements.text: Any way to ensure that compat bounds stay "correct"? Suppose I started developing package A and put B=0.1 in its dependencies. Then new versions of B come out, and A's compat is now B=0.1,0.2,0.3,0.4. But turns out that A uses some feature that appeared in B@0.3, and is not compatible with earlier versions anymore. How to catch this?
installs latest versions that fit compats, so it will never catch the failure.

Hello, I'm a new comer to Julia, and I was going through the Docs and I saw that the same function is defined twice, once as a method and once as a function.
This is the first time I have encountered something like this. Could someone please explain why is this convention followed and what is the difference between the two?
PS: I apologize if I am not messaging in the right channel :sweat_smile:

messages.text:
Oh boy you get world age issues, but not world-age errors.
```module HACK
    function foo()
        if !isdefined(@__MODULE__, :foo_cache)
            eval(:(const foo_cache = 1; foo()=10))
            return 1
        end
        return 100
    end
end

bar() = HACK.foo() + HACK.foo()
bar()```
result is  `101`
Is this a julia bug?

root.text:
how would I write a function method which when called the first time computes some data, stores it in a variable, then "replaces" itself with a new method that uses the stored data? I'd imagine something like this pseudo code:
```function foo(x::T)
  global mycache
  if !isdefined(mycache)
    mycache = expensive_computation() # actually ideally should be made a global const?!
    replace_foo_by( x -> cheap_computation(mycache, x)) # <- how could this be done?
  end
  return cheap_computation(mycache, x)
end```

attachments.title: RustFFT 5.0.0-experimental.1: Now faster than FFTW!
attachments.text: Today, I released RustFFT 5.0.0-experimental.1! RustFFT is a high-performance FFT library written in pure Rust. Version 5.0.0-experimental.1 implements AVX acceleration and is 5x-10x faster than RustFFT 4.0.0 at every FFT size. More notably, with this release, RustFFT beats FFTW in performance, one of the industry-leading FFT libraries! To make the comparison, I used the Fourier crate's very useful benchmarks, which compare the performance of RustFFT, Fourier, and FFTW. I found that, at every ...

messages.text: Can't use `a(end-1)` etc with round brackets.

Figured I'd ask people for thoughts on syntax before making a change:
VectorizationBase's `Vec <: Real` , and tries to generally emulate the behavior of other number types; subtle differences in behavior between a `Vec` and a number could yield subtle bugs in LoopVectorization (which uses these `Vec` s).

This can be annoying:
```julia> using VectorizationBase

julia> vx = Vec(ntuple(_ -> 10randn(), VectorizationBase.pick_vector_width_val(Float64))...)
Vec{8,Float64}<-4.245283169836398, 1.5841992084221632, 5.349305073522918, -11.665069338111593, 7.232457145962249, 6.359977099223897, -2.143514184415122, -1.2492126085866504>

julia> a = 2.3
2.3

julia> a[1]
2.3

julia> vx[1]
Vec{8,Float64}<-4.245283169836398, 1.5841992084221632, 5.349305073522918, -11.665069338111593, 7.232457145962249, 6.359977099223897, -2.143514184415122, -1.2492126085866504>

julia> VectorizationBase.extractelement(vx, 0) # zero-based
-4.245283169836398```
Discoverability of `extractelement` is also low (should write more docs!), and could lead to someone to...
```julia> dump(vx)
Vec{8, Float64}
  data: NTuple{8, VecElement{Float64}}
    1: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 -4.245283169836398
    2: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 1.5841992084221632
    3: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 5.349305073522918
    4: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 -11.665069338111593
    5: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 7.232457145962249
    6: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 6.359977099223897
    7: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 -2.143514184415122
    8: VecElement{Float64}
      value: Float64 -1.2492126085866504

julia> vx.data[1].value
-4.245283169836398```
Which is less than ideal, as this sort of thing is likely to cause work codegen.

So, my thought is to copy Fortran/MATLAB, because calling isn't taken:
```julia> a(4)
ERROR: MethodError: objects of type Float64 are not callable
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[41]:1```
and also make it 1-based for familiarity / convenient conversion to tuples via `ntuple(vx, Val(8))`.
Thoughts/good use of syntax?

Not really better in terms of discoverability, so doc issues will still need to be addressed.

messages.text:
Well this is fun. NamedDims.jl + ComponentArrays.jl is a really nice combination, it turns out.

```using ComponentArrays: ComponentArray
using ForwardDiff: jacobian!
using NamedDims: NamedDimsArray
using UnPack: @unpack

body = ComponentArray(pos=(x=1.0, y=2, z=3), vel=(x=4, y=5, z=7))
D_body = zero(body)
J = NamedDimsArray{(:func, :var)}(0 * body * body')

function elastic_pendulum!(D, vars)
    @unpack pos, vel = vars
    ω² = 3
    L = 2
    g = 10

    r = sqrt(sum(pos.^2))

    D.pos .= vel
    D.vel .= -ω² * (r - L)/r * pos
    D.vel.z -= g
end

jacobian!(J, elastic_pendulum!, D_body, body)```
```julia> J[func=:vel, var=:pos]
3×3 NamedDimsArray{(:func, :var),Float64,2,ComponentMatrix{Float64,SubArray...}}:
 -1.51097   -0.229081  -0.343622
 -0.229081  -1.85459   -0.687243
 -0.343622  -0.687243  -2.4273

julia> J[func=:vel, var=:pos][func=:x, var=:y]
-0.22908106449636378

julia> J[func=:pos, var=:vel][func=:x, var=:x]
1.0```

elements.text: Well this is fun. NamedDims.jl + ComponentArrays.jl is a really nice combination, it turns out.

using ComponentArrays: ComponentArray
using ForwardDiff: jacobian!
using NamedDims: NamedDimsArray
using UnPack: @unpack

body = ComponentArray(pos=(x=1.0, y=2, z=3), vel=(x=4, y=5, z=7))
D_body = zero(body)
J = NamedDimsArray{(:func, :var)}(0 * body * body')

function elastic_pendulum!(D, vars)
    @unpack pos, vel = vars
    ω² = 3
    L = 2
    g = 10

    r = sqrt(sum(pos.^2))

    D.pos .= vel
    D.vel .= -ω² * (r - L)/r * pos
    D.vel.z -= g
end

jacobian!(J, elastic_pendulum!, D_body, body)

julia> J[func=:vel, var=:pos]
3×3 NamedDimsArray{(:func, :var),Float64,2,ComponentMatrix{Float64,SubArray...}}:
 -1.51097   -0.229081  -0.343622
 -0.229081  -1.85459   -0.687243
 -0.343622  -0.687243  -2.4273

julia> J[func=:vel, var=:pos][func=:x, var=:y]
-0.22908106449636378

julia> J[func=:pos, var=:vel][func=:x, var=:x]
1.0

messages.text: Alright people, cloudflare has written some C to calculate euclidean distances in 144 dimensions for UInt8 Coordinates. Blog & Code is in the Thread. Their fastest version is `mmdist-short-inv-avx2.c`, is ~200 LOC and runs in ~0.728ms per query on their system. Can we make this as fast (or maybe faster? :eyes:) with less code that is more readable?

messages.text:
Conda != Anaconda
Conda is the package manager, it's fully open source

Anaconda is a distribution of python and related tool made by Continuum Analytics.
It has Conda, and Python, a ton of libraries preinstalled and I think a editor or two, and it makes heavy use of Conda to install it's parts.
It's not open source, but we don't use it

root.text:
Hi, I have a question to the IJulia.jl.
It uses Conda.jl as a dependency. Conda itself is not free for commercial usage. So in order to use IJulia.jl legally in larger company, one must buy a conda license?

messages.text: What's up with `display(::MIME"text/plain", ::String)` displaying the quoted string? This seems out of sync with other MIME types like `text/html` or `text/markdown` where the string is interpreted as the raw data encoded in that format, whereas `text/plain` shows the representation of the string as a Julia value like it would appear in code. Is there a way to tell `display` that I want to show the string as-is?

elements.text: displaying the quoted string? This seems out of sync with other MIME types like

attachments.fallback:
[December 14th, 2020 4:41 PM] pranshumalik14: I came across a weird compile behaviour that I don't understand. Given the function:
```@inline function num_unique(group_str::AbstractString)
    return group_str |> Set |> length
end```
I have defined a super function (with two variants and their output and lowered code). Variant 1:
```function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    f = x -> replace(x, "\n" => "")
    return group_strs .|> f .|> num_unique |> sum
end```
Output of variant 1:
```sum_unique(group_strs) = 6703```
Lowered code of variant 1:
```@code_lowered sum_unique(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #23 = %new(Main.:(var"#23#24"))
│        f = #23
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, f)
│   %4 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, %3, Main.num_unique)
│   %5 = Base.materialize(%4)
│   %6 = %5 |> Main.sum
└──      return %6
)```
Now the okay-looking (to me) variant 2:
```function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    return group_strs .|> x -> replace(x, "\n" => "") .|> num_unique |> sum
end```
Output of variant 2:
```sum_unique(group_strs) = [3, 16, 22, 22, ...] # sum(output array) = 6703```
Lowered code of variant 2:
```@code_lowered sum_unique2(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #27 = %new(Main.:(var"#27#28"))
│   %2 = #27
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, %2)
│   %4 = Base.materialize(%3)
└──      return %4 # doesn't even call sum and just exits!
)```
I am not sure why this is happening. What is wrong with chaining after an anonymous function?

I came across a weird compile behaviour that I don't understand. Given the function:
```@inline function num_unique(group_str::AbstractString)
    return group_str |> Set |> length
end```
I have defined a super function (with two variants and their output and lowered code). Variant 1:
```function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    f = x -> replace(x, "\n" => "")
    return group_strs .|> f .|> num_unique |> sum
end```
Output of variant 1:
```sum_unique(group_strs) = 6703```
Lowered code of variant 1:
```@code_lowered sum_unique(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #23 = %new(Main.:(var"#23#24"))
│        f = #23
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, f)
│   %4 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, %3, Main.num_unique)
│   %5 = Base.materialize(%4)
│   %6 = %5 |> Main.sum
└──      return %6
)```
Now the okay-looking (to me) variant 2:
```function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    return group_strs .|> x -> replace(x, "\n" => "") .|> num_unique |> sum
end```
Output of variant 2:
```sum_unique(group_strs) = [3, 16, 22, 22, ...] # sum(output array) = 6703```
Lowered code of variant 2:
```@code_lowered sum_unique2(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #27 = %new(Main.:(var"#27#28"))
│   %2 = #27
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, %2)
│   %4 = Base.materialize(%3)
└──      return %4 # doesn't even call sum and just exits!
)```
I am not sure why this is happening. What is wrong with chaining after an anonymous function?

attachments.title: The Julia Programming Language
attachments.text: Julia is a high-performance, dynamic programming language for modern technical computing. It solves the two language problem by being simultaneously as fast as C and as easy as Python. The built-in package manager provides access to over 4,000 Julia packages created by the Julia community, in addition to foreign function interfaces for tens of thousands of C, Fortran, Python, and R libraries. The Julia package ecosystem includes best in class packages in a number of ecosystems: Image Processing, Machine Learning, Data Science, Optimization, Parallel computing, Cloud computing, Automatic Differentiation, Graph Processing, Probabilistic Programming, Finite Elements, Computational Biology, Ecology, Climate science, Astrophysics, Quantum Computing, and much more.
